title: How to Run Productive and Creative Meetings
headline: Master the skills to organize your workspace and meetings for optimal productivity with this free online course.
description: Is your workspace organized? Are your meetings lacking energy, creativity or productivity? This free online course will help you organize your work area for maximum productivity and give you the tools to start holding more productive meetings that generate new ideas and boost creativity. Rethink what you know about productivity and learn the guiding principles to gear your work environment and day-to-day schedule for consistent output.

courseDescription:
We have all experienced neverending, boring, go-nowhere meetings that feel like an utter waste of time. This free online course will help you organize your workspace to boost your overall productivity and creativity and guide you on how to improve the quality of your meetings. In the first section, you will explore some guiding principles by which you should organize your work area for maximum comfort and productivity. You will learn the key benefits of arranging your space to have everything easily accessible. The course covers real-life workspace experience, highlighting things that are right - and wrong - about it. It discusses the small changes that you can make right now to rearrange your desk area such as optimal lighting, preferred electronic devices such as keyboards and mouses, managing meals (and why you should not eat at your desk!), the appropriate cleaning wipes for your electronics and how to create a ‘to-do’ space.

The next section discusses how to boost your creativity in a meeting and get away from that dreaded feeling that arises when you gather for a discussion. You will be shown how to organize your meetings and switch things up, not just by being creative, but also by helping you understand how to make your meetings as productive as possible. This section aims to help you keep everyone focused and interested and how an ideal meeting setup allows creativity to kick in. Learn how silencing chit-chat and starting a meeting on a positive note can trigger further creativity and how to motivate participants with food or other incentives. When to take notes, the use of ‘opposites’ and ‘And/Or’ exercises to boost the output of your meetings will also be explained. Some other themes include how to achieve success without a table, split participants into groups, come up with inspiring brainstorming exercises, the advantages of having your meetings outside the four walls of your organization and benefits of having well-known or reputable guests appear. The last section will teach you how to run meetings so that they are productive. Discover why every meeting should have a facilitator, how different seating arrangements can have different outcomes, how to open a discussion, set an agenda and examples of agenda and when to wrap-up. You also will study how to deal with various personality types in a meeting to improve team dynamics and all about the seven different types of meetings and how to make each of them successful.

This course is for anyone including those in a home-office or remote environment, company or group who wants to organize their work environment to boost their overall productivity and take their meetings to the next level. Enrolling in this productivity course can have great long-term benefits for your professional life as well as any organization you may work in.

Start Course Now

Once you have completed this certificate course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison certificate is:

  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:

  • certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked certificate, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked certificate in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will learn how to organize your workspace for maximum productivity. The desk organizer, whiteboard, shelves, and how to use them to organize your items will be explained. You will also study the types of lighting systems to use in your work environment, the proper electronics, and cleaning wipes for your desk and electronics.
topics: Everything Must Have Its Own Place

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will learn how to build a creative meeting environment. The importance of encouraging creativity in and out of meetings will be explained. You will also be taken through some creative boosting exercises such as the never-ending AND/OR, brainstorming exercises, etc. that should be employed in your meetings to boost productivity.
topics: Creativity Boosting For Classrooms, Organizations, & Small Groups

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will learn how to run meetings so that they are productive and what you hope to achieve is actually done. How to arrange the seats for a meeting, best practices to open a meeting, as well as the ideal length of a meeting will be explained. Seven different types of meetings and how to run them will be discussed in this section.
topics: How to Make Meetings More Productive
Types of Meetings and How to Run Them

    • Discuss how to organize your workspace or area for maximum productivity
    • Identify the appropriate cleaning wipes for your electronic devices
    • Arrange the things in your workspace or area so that they can be easily accessible
    • Identify a suitable lighting system for your work environment

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are:
  • The benefits of having everything in its own place are as follows:
    1. It saves you time when looking for something.
    2. Your desk will be cleaner and organized so that you can have peace of mind.
  • Some of the items to help organize your workspace and stay focused are as follows: 
    1. Shelves: Used to store files and documents.
    2. Desk organizers: Used to store files and documents.
    3. Whiteboard: Helps you write your big ideas down so that you can focus on them. It is advisable to have them as big as possible.
    4. Wireless devices: Keyboards, mouse, etc. They make your workspace more clear and cleaner.
    5. Cleaning wipes: These can be used to clean your desk and electronic devices and helps to deal with bacteria around your workspace.
  • There are two kinds of lights around your workspace. The natural light and the fluorescent light or bulb. Some studies have suggested that natural lights are better for your work and creativity. If you can not get that, the more light you can get is better.
  • One guiding principle of organizing your workspace is that everything should be a hand's reach away so that you can stay focus on your work.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Define a creative meeting
    • Discuss how to be creative and productive in a meeting
    • Explain the importance of creative silence in a meeting
    • State how to achieve creativity by taking a brainstorming exercise
    • Arrange a meeting outside the walls of your institution or organization

  • Beyond the Notepad Meeting Exercise

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are:
  • Creativity can kick in when people come out of a meeting laughing, joking, relaxed and you can come up with some great ideas.
  • Part of encouraging creativity is to never shut an idea down because the moment you shut that idea down, there is a high chance that person will never share the next great idea.
  • Turning creativity into a game with incentives will get everyone's attention so that at the end of the meeting you state what problems your idea has to solve, by when and the high-value price that idea will win.
  • Below are some creative boosting exercises  to boost your meetings:
    1. Beyond the notepad exercise: Switch your notepad with a table cover, covering the entire table, and let people write their ideas on this table cover.
    2. Opposite exercise: Share the opposite ideas of your problems or meeting topic. With this exercise, a lot of people will give you their ideas and thereby increasing engagement and get everyone creative on stuck.
    3. Never-ending AND/OR exercise: For this exercise, you will give your team a topic or a problem and they will take turns going around without judging at a fast pace, connecting each other's ideas with the word 'and' or 'or'.
    4. Right vs. left exercise: This is to ask your team or group to split into two groups. One will be the right and the other will be the lift. Depending on the size of the group, you can ask them to come up with three or more ideas on the topic of their choice.
    5. Beyond the wall exercise: Taking your meetings outside the walls of your office or organization. The outside life can wake up your senses.
    6. Inviting a guest appearance: If there seems to be a lack of creativity in your team or meetings, it could be because there is a lack of motivation. One way to boost creativity in your meetings is to have a guest or a famous person appear in one of your meetings.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Outline seven different types of meetings and how to make each type a success
    • State when to hold a problem-solving meeting
    • Discuss how to deal with people who hijack meetings
    • Arrange the appropriate seating arrangement for a meeting
    • Define a status update meeting

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are:
  • The following are key points to make a meeting more productive.
    • Every meeting should have a facilitator. The facilitator is the person who organizes the meetings and makes sure that the meeting runs smoothly.
    • Every meeting should have a stated time set limit so that the participants will note the time to take to achieve their goals.
    • Every meeting should have a stated goal or agenda. It is best practice for the facilitator to create this ahead of time and send it to everyone in the meeting.
    • Some people like to talk for a while or talk very slow and make few points in a lot of time. The facilitator should have some rules that a person can not talk about longer than that. It is also okay to interrupt a person who goes beyond that limit.
  • The following are some types of meetings
    1. Status update meetings: These are meetings held regularly and the idea behind them is to get different group members to align what they are working on.
    2. Information sharing meetings: There are meetings where one presenter shares information with other people on the team.
    3. Decision-making meetings: These are meetings where a group of experts meets to decide on a particular topic or matter. Not only do you end up wanting to make a decision but you want to outline the steps to make that decision.
    4. Team building meetings: This is where you want everyone to know each other from your team. It helps especially where there are remote workers.
    5. Problem-solving meetings: These meetings should be held before the problem arises. If you have a business plan, it means you have made plans ahead for the problems and are very easy to solve if plans are made ahead of it.
    6. Sales and negotiation meetings: These meetings are complex. Before you go to these meetings, you have to think through what you will be happy with, if you buying or selling a product, etc.
